prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HD 10647
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Image the HD 10647 debris disk and star in 1.3 mm continuum emission (and search for CO 2-1 line emission).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is primarily a continuum project, so we configure the correlator to achieve the maximum 7.5 GHz bandwidth for maximum continuum sensitivity. We place one spectral window on the CO 2-1 line with channel width 1.27 km/s, sufficient to resolve orbital velocities at 10's of AU around this Solar mass star.

We require angular resolution high enough (1) to resolve the structure of the dust belt emission, and (2) detect the stellar photosphere and belt centroid offsets corresponding to eccentricities < 0.1 (Figure 2, third panel). These requirements drive the needed beam size to about 0.6 arcsec. The maximum angular scale is the full extent of the emission belt, nominally about 12 arcsec, although the relevant largest scale is effectively the smaller width of the inclined belt. The C36-3 configuration spans the full range of required angular scales. The full flux density is recovered by the shortest baselines of the main array; the ACA is not required. The full extent of the source emission fits within a single pointing at band 6.

We use the full 7.5 GHz bandwidth to maximize continuum sensitivity. We request 14 microJy rms at band 6, driven by the desire to obtain a solid (>4 x rms) detection of the stellar photosphere, 60 microJy at 1.3 mm. Our CASA simulations show that this sensitivity will provide a typical signal-to-noise ratio >10 per beam on the dust belt emission for a variety of physical scenarios of interest (Figure 2). These simulations assume a total disk flux of 6 mJy at 1.3mm, which is strongly constrained by the submillimeter spectrum, but conservatively much lower (by a factor of 2) than implied by the APEX single dish 870 micron measurement of Liseau et al. 2008 that appears to be contaminated by a background source located to the east of the star.
The spectral line aspect is a secondary detection experiment only. The 1.27 km/s velocity resolution is sufficient to resolve orbital velocities at 10's of AU around this Solar mass star. The observations will be sensitive to CO 2-1 line emission of 6 mJy per beam per velocity bin.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HD 139664
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Image the HD 139664 debris disk and star in 1.3 mm continuum emission (and search for CO 2-1 line emission).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is primarily a continuum project, so we configure the correlator to achieve the maximum 7.5 GHz bandwidth for maximum continuum sensitivity. We place one spectral window on the CO 2-1 line with resolution 1.27 km/s, sufficient to resolve orbital velocities at 10's of AU around this Solar mass star.

We require angular resolution high enough (1) to resolve the structure of the dust belt emission, and (2) detect the stellar photosphere and belt centroid offsets corresponding to eccentricities < 0.1 (as in Figure 2 for HD 10647). These requirements drive the needed beam size to about 0.6 arcsec. The maximum angular scale is the full extent of the belt, nominally about 12 arcsec, although the relevant largest scale is effectively the much smaller width of the inclined belt. The C36-3 configuration spans the full range of required angular scales. Our simulations show that the full flux density is recovered by the shortest baselines of the main array; the ACA is not required. The full extent of the source emission fits within a single pointing at band 6.

We use the full 7.5 GHz bandwidth to maximize continuum sensitivity. We request 14 microJy rms at band 6, driven by the desire to obtain a solid (>4 x rms) detection of the stellar photosphere, 70 microJy at 1.3 mm. The CASA simulations for this system, which has a more highly inclined than HD 10647 (Figure 2), show that this sensitivity will provide a typical signal-to-noise ratio >10 per beam on the dust belt emission despite a lower total disk flux of about 2.5 mJy at 1.3 mm, estimated from the available shorter wavelength data (and consistent with the 3 sigma upper limit < 11 mJy at 870 microns of Nilsson et al. 2010).
The spectral line aspect is a secondary detection experiment only. The 1.27 km/s velocity resolution is sufficient to resolve orbital velocities at 10's of AU around this Solar mass star. The observations will be sensitive to CO 2-1 line emission of 6 mJy per beam per velocity bin.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HD 207129
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Image the HD 207129 debris disk and star in 1.3 mm continuum emission (and search for CO 2-1 line emission).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is primarily a continuum project, so we configure the correlator to achieve the maximum 7.5 GHz bandwidth for maximum continuum sensitivity. We place one spectral window on the CO 2-1 line with channel width 1.27 km/s, sufficient to resolve orbital velocities at 10's of AU around this Solar mass star.

We require angular resolution high enough (1) to resolve the structure of the dust belt emission, and (2) detect the stellar photosphere and belt centroid offsets corresponding to eccentricities < 0.1 (as in Figure 2 for HD 10647). These requirements drive the needed beam size to about 0.6 arcsec. The maximum angular scale is the full extent of the emission belt, nominally about 20 arcsec, although the relevant largest scale is effectively the smaller width of the inclined belt. The C36-3 configuration spans the full range of required angular scales. Our simualtions show that the full flux density of this large emission belt is recovered by the shortest baselines of the main array; the ACA is not required. The full extent of the source emission fits within a single pointing at band 6.

We use the full 7.5 GHz bandwidth to maximize continuum sensitivity. We request 14 microJy rms at band 6, driven by the desire to obtain a solid (4 x rms) detection of the stellar photosphere, 60 microJy at 1.3 mm. The CASA simulations for this source, which is more spatially extended than HD 10647 (Figure 2), show that this sensitivity will provide a typical signal-to-noise ratio >4 per beam on the dust belt emission (and a modest taper to 1 arcsec can improve the surface brightness sensitivity, depending on the details of the belt structure). Our simulations assume a total disk flux of 1.8 mJy at 1.3 mm, estimated very conservatively from the Herschel submillimeter spectral data to 500 microns, and consistent with the (low signal-to-noise) measurement of 5.1 +/- 2.7 mJy at 870 microns reported by Nilsson et al. 2010.
The spectral line aspect is a secondary detection experiment only. The 1.27 km/s velocity is sufficient to resolve orbital velocities at 10's of AU around this Solar mass star. The observations will be sensitive to CO 2-1 line emission of 6 mJy per beam per velocity bin.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HD 38858
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Image the HD 38858 debris disk and star in 1.3 mm continuum emission (and search for CO 2-1 line emission).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is primarily a continuum project, so we configure the correlator to achieve the maximum 7.5 GHz bandwidth for maximum continuum sensitivity. We place one spectral window on the CO 2-1 line with channel width 1.27 km/s, sufficient to resolve orbital velocities at 10's of AU around this Solar mass star.

We require angular resolution high enough (1) to resolve the structure of the dust belt emission, and (2) detect the stellar photosphere and belt centroid offsets corresponding to eccentricities < 0.1 (as in Figure 2 for HD 10647). These requirements drive the needed beam size to about 0.5 arcsec. The maximum angular scale is the full extent of the emission belt, nominally about 16 arcsec, although the relevant largest scale is effectively the smaller width of the belt. The C36-3 configuration spans the full range of required angular scales. The full flux density is recovered by the shortest baselines of the main array; the ACA is not required. The full extent of the source emission fits within a single pointing at band 6.

We use the full 7.5 GHz bandwidth to maximize continuum sensitivity. We request 13.5 microJy rms at band 6, driven by the desire to obtain a solid (4 x rms) detection of the stellar photosphere, 56 microJy at 1.3 mm. The CASA simulations for this source show that this sensitivity will provide a typical signal-to-noise ratio >5 per beam on the dust belt emission. These simulations assume a total disk flux of 2.5 mJy at 1.3 mm, based on the the measurement of 7.5 +/- 2 mJy at 850 microns of Kennedy et al. 2015 and a spectral slope of 2.5; the analysis is robust to the uncertainties in this flux estimate.
The spectral line aspect is a secondary detection experiment only. The 1.27 km/s velocity resolution is sufficient to resolve orbital velocities at 10's of AU around this Solar mass star. The observations will be sensitive to CO 2-1 line emission of 6 mJy per beam per velocity bin.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to image the millimeter continuum emission from a sample of the brightest debris disks around the closest (< 20 pc) Sun-like (FGK) main-sequence stars to probe the underlying distributions of dust-producing planetesimals. We will use these data to (1) quantify the surface density structures and assess if the central clearings of these disks result from collisional depletion by an outward moving front of planetoid growth, or dynamical depletion from the gravitational influence of giant planets, (2) use disk features including sharp disk edges, offsets, and azimuthal asymmetries to place constraints on otherwise inaccessible wide-separation planets, and (3) make the first systematic comparative study of the planetesimal structures around Sun-like stars of ~Gyr ages. Analysis of these closest debris disks will provide the cornerstone templates for interpretion of more distant, less accessible systems.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
